The filter related portlets (Filter Statistics & Two Dimensional Filter Statistics) should be removed gracefully if the associated filter has been removed.

At present, the 'Edit Portlet' and 'Delete Portlet' links are still available if the filter has been removed. These should be removed (at the very least - the edit link should be removed).

The backup XML file contains a lot of paths to files, including the attachments, old cache, backup locations etc. The administrator can't view these without importing the file and if for example the attachments directory isn't where Jira expects it, the system is in inconsistent state when it's up after the restoration.

Optimally the backup process would work like this:

1) Tell Jira where the backup file is located
2) Jira scans the XML file and locates all the paths within the file
3) Administrator is presented with a page which lists those paths and allows editing them
4) Jira then restores the DB and replaces the paths stored in the XML with the paths the administrator provided
fields.summary: Graceful backup restoration is very hard if server path structure doesn't reflect backup XML

We are handling lots of single projects, with single project-groups, which mustn't see each others projects.

Therefore assume we want to setup a new Project named "X-Project". Then we do the following steps:
1. Create a group named "X-Project"
2. Create users
3. Click every single user into the group (boooring)
4. Create a Permission Scheme from a template Scheme through copy
4b. Rename the Scheme to "X-Project"
4c. Add the "X-Project"-group to the right permissions
5. Create a Layout-Scheme from a template Scheme through copy
5b. Rename the Scheme to "X-Project"
6. Create a Notification Scheme from a template Scheme through copy
6b. Rename the Scheme to "X-Project"
7. FINALLY! Create a Project !!! And Assign all Schemes to it !!!

OK, this was just to show you how much time and effort it takes to setup projects like this. 

THIS is, what i think would improve this SOMEWHAT:

THE ALL NEW CREATE PROJECT PAGE !
Here is what it looks like:
   - Like today: Name, Project Lead, etc.

   - For each scheme (Notification, Permission, Layout, Security) you either select an existing
     one (like today) of you select one and also activate a checkbox which reads (create from  
     template)
   - if the "create from template" checkbox is activated for a selected scheme, this scheme 
     gets copied and renamed to the name of the project after you click the Create Button
   - There is another checkbox : Create "Project Group". If this checkbox is activated a 
     group will be created, which is named exactly like the project
   - Click "Create"
   - Everything gets created
   - You are asked, which users to add to the new project group (if you created such a group) and 
     you can select them from a listbox (with multi-select) and click on add. These users are then      added to the new group
   - Done - you get navigated to the newly created project administration page

The only thing left to do would be editing the new schemes. Or has anyone good ideas how to get the scheme editing neatly into this process?
fields.summary: Super-Easy Project Setup incl. Group, Permissions, Layouts and Users
Custom Field: Attach File
Make gadgets and reports interchangeable
Horizontal positioning in field layout schemes

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – November 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thank you for watching, voting, and commenting on this issue. We understand this has been a long running request. We also understand this has caused a lot of frustration so I don't want to ignore that fact, but I do hope to strike a chord of optimism with this update.

A recap of the current workarounds:

*(1) Utilising team-managed projects*
 # From your project sidebar, go to {*}Project settings > Issue types{*}.

 # Select *Description* and update the default description you want to see when you’re creating an issue.

*(2) Add Description text for a field*

Note: Before you begin, you’ll need to [set up a field configuration scheme for your issue types in your project|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-cloud-administration/docs/configure-a-field-configuration-scheme/].

To update the description for the *Description* field:
 # Go to *Settings* {*}> Issues > Field configuration{*}.

 # Select {*}Field configuration{*}.

 # Under {*}Actions{*}, select {*}Configure{*}.

 # Find the *Description* field, and select {*}Edit{*}.

 # Update the description for the field 'Description' in the text box.

The description you add will come up when you create an issue of a certain issue type if it has been associated with the screen. [Learn more about associating fields with screens|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-cloud-administration/docs/change-a-field-configuration/].

*(3) Configure automation rules for your system fields.*

There’s some suggested workflows from other community members in [[Default text for Description field on Jira Cloud|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-questions/Default-text-for-Description-field-on-Jira-Cloud/qaq-p/785597]]

[Learn more about automation rules in Jira cloud|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-software-cloud/docs/create-and-edit-rules/].

 

As for building the feature to add default values to system fields in company-managed projects, it is still on our radar.

For transparency, there’s a number of foundational pieces we are working on in order to unblock this feature. At this stage we hope to be able to start work on this in 12 months - we understand it’s a long time and we ask for your continued patience as we work through the implementation.

Please continue to vote and in particular please continue to add comments on how your teams find value when using default values for system fields. This feedback on your specific needs and use cases is invaluable for us as we continue to evolve Jira Cloud.

 

Regards, 
Carol Low
Product Manager, Jira Cloud
{panel}

Our JIRA 2.6.1 currently has 70 projects. A dozen of them are loosely related, and lead by a single person. The poor chap has to run lots of saved searches to get a crisp view of what's going on in his projects.

Adding the ability to search issues belonging to projects lead by a specific user would be a great thing for him.

Another use-case in which such a feature is quite useful:

Sometimes, some of our project leaders go on vacation, or have to leave the office for several days without any mean nor time to connect to JIRA. 
In these cases, another person has to handle the projects. The backup leader then has to setup a few filters to search accross the relevant projects for activity. It would be much easier to be able to make a single search based on project leader.

Other ways to achieve similar results are JRA-2837 or JRA-2755
fields.summary: Allow searching for issues based on project leader

h3. Symptoms

When using the [Database Integrity Checker|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Using+the+Database+Integrity+Checker] a stack trace is generated.

The following may be found within the {{atlassian-jira.log}}:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.exception.IntegrityException: Error occurred while performing check.
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.check.WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.doCheck(WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.java:142)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.check.WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.preview(WorkflowCurrentStepCheck.java:51)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.IntegrityChecker.preview(IntegrityChecker.java:63)
	at com.atlassian.jira.appconsistency.integrity.IntegrityChecker.previewWithIds(IntegrityChecker.java:35)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.IntegrityChecker.doExecute(IntegrityChecker.java:68)
	at webwork.action.ActionSupport.execute(ActionSupport.java:165)
{noformat}

h3. Cause

This is a bug within JIRA.

h3. Workaround

Run the "Check Issue for Relation 'RelatedOSWorkflowEntry'" check first and fix any entries that are returned.

> The CVS integration in Jira 3 Preview has improved a lot and now it can be 
> considered finally usable when one has more than just a couple of source 
> files (tested the Professional Standalone version) !
> 
> But it only works nicely if the 'CVS modules' are simple directories in the 
> repository. Unfortunately we have been exploiting quite heavily a standard 
> feature of CVS called 'alias modules' and this gives now the new Jira CVS 
> integration a headache.
> 
> To simplify it when we checkout a single module 'env_projectx' it is 
> actually an alias module which collects things on the server side and comes 
> out in physical files as
> root/struct_common
> root/struct_projectx
> ...
> 
> and still having the correct direct CVS repository details of the server

Note: This issue has been discussed on the jira-user list in http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=6072&tstart=0

Some reports should allow configuration of the report inside the report page itself. This would allow the user to modify the report params without having to constantly switch back and forth between pages.

Example 1:

+---
| #Config section
| Report for group [Atlassian Developers|V]
| [X] Show Workload of individual product versions
+----
| # Report Data (remaining workload in days per developer per version)
|            |             | Mike        | Scott | ...
| -----------+-------------+-------------+-------+--------
| Jira       | Version 3.0 | 14          | 5
|            | Version 3.1 | 6           | 23
+------------+-------------+------ ...
| Confluence | Version 1.2 | 26

Example 2 (Version splitting turned off):

+---
| #Config section
| Report for group [Atlassian Developers|V]
| [ ] Show Workload of individual product versions
+----
| # Report Data (remaining workload in days per developer)
|            | Mike        | Scott | ...
| -----------+-------------+-------+-------+--------
| Jira       | 20          | 28
+------------+-------------+------ ...
| Confluence | 26


It is today possible to implement this (see forum thread mentioned above), but it's clumsy, involves duplicating original Jira code, and each plugin developer has do do this for each plugin.

A declarative solution would be much easier for the plugin developer, e.g.:

<resource type="velocity" name="view"
    location="templates/plugins/jira/reports/time-tracking-report.vm">

    <!-- default would be false -->
    <property name="allowInlineConfiguration" value="true"/>
</resource>

Jira would do all the plumbing for the plugin developer (include fields, generate form submission code, etc.).

A further improvement suggested by Owen: Might be worth allowing each property to be inlineConfigurable so you can just have some filter that are refined.
fields.summary: Allow inline configuration of reports

An extra permission is needed to allow Reporters to be able to Assign To Me, providing they are also have the Assignable User permission, but despite not having the Assign User permission.

This avoids the situation where a user can report an issue they are able to address themselves (but don't have permissions to directly assign to another user) but have to wait for the project lead (or some other appropriately permissioned user) to assign it back to the reporter.

May be addressed by some of the other related requests to do with field-level permissions in 2.7 and beyond.

h3. Workaround

A transition can be added that will allow assigning to current user, without requiring the *Assign User* [Project Permissions|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Project+Permissions]. This is explained in further detail in [Advanced workflow configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+workflow+configuration].

# Edit the workflow.
# Add the transition 'Assign to Current User' and set the destination status as the current status.
# Update the Post-function to use the 'Assign to Current User'.
# Edit the condition so that it's only available for certain users, for example 'User is in Project Role'. This can also be done for other permissions, or groups. 
# Add those users to the appropriate project role, group or permission.
# Publish the workflow.

Now users with that specific permission will be able to use the 'Assign to Current User' transition.
fields.summary: Extra permission "Assign Issues To Self If Reporter"

JIRA is well-engineered, but as a heavy application generally run on a single server and doing a great deal of work to generate each information-filled page, it is not exactly "fast."  Page loads are quite reasonable, but the workflow effect of having to fully load a new page after every action makes extensive work inside JIRA much slower than it should be.

The interface is very well-designed, but even on a fast server with no load it can rarely keep up with the user because of the page-to-page latency.

Inspired by astonishingly fast web interfaces which make creative use of DHTML and client-side rendering, such as Gmail, I think it would be exceedingly useful if JIRA's interface were to evolve in this direction.

The current, indirect solution to this is to load the static pages with as much related information/form fields as possible, to reduce the frequency of loading new pages, but this has the unwanted side-effect of over-burdening many form pages with a great many large forms.

* Menus, lists (comments), etc. expand dynamically
* Forms/controls expand dynamically, a la the Gmail quick-reply/forward box
  - all pages from which one might next click an "edit" type link could have the primary linked forms embedded but hidden, so they could be opened without having to open a new page
* Dynamic view switching, as in how Gmail allows the view to switch between the current mailbox and the currently selected message without reloading the page

And if this could further be matched with quick keyboard navigation, like Gmail, the web interface would be fantastic.

Version numbers are very difficult to work with, and provide poor semantics.

Adding a new version requires multiple steps: add the version, schedule the version. This should be single step. Maybe by selecting the before/after existing version when adding. (Often we are adding versions to our production branch, but the development branch version has already been created and should remain the last version.

Well, if version were richer in semantics, the above would be a non-issue. Often we have version like:

10.0
10.1
10.2
11.0
11.1

But jira sees these as only text strings. The ability to treat version hierarchically would be very helpful:

10     (where this represents a major version)
.10.0  (these reprent minor versions, or patches)
.10.1
.10.2

If this semantic was part of the model, reordering would not be required. Of course, this semantic would need to be configurable as I'm sure some users really do want just text values. But I suspect most really use numbers as above.

The concept of released/non-released seems only to be manifest in the selection lists when selecting versions. We would like to place restrictions on what affects-versions can be assigned to a [new] issue. For example, in our process, it never makes sense for a non-developer (eg, group jira-developer) to assing a version to a non-released version. Our users/tests are always assigning issues non-sensical versions (ie, a bug against a version that has not been deployed). 

Extending the released/non-released to versions in development/test/production would be very helpful. Of course, this is just one example of assinging meta-data to the version. Others will want other values for the, say, version state. Some will want other meta-data, like comments associated with a version. But mainly we are looking for the ability to control the workflow based on the version meta-data.

The simple stringness of version makes it difficult to create a ant-task that can bounce version numbers are part of a deployment. I've looked into the code, and yes, it would not be too hard manipulate the versions. But it would require parsing and such. If version had first-class semantics, statements such as: "Create the next version the v10 line". If v10.4 was the current last version, v10.5 would be created. And if v11.x already existed, v10.5. would be scheduled prior to any v11's. 

Again, this makes assumptions about the meaning of version. I know you wanted to leave much flexibility. Maybe some kind of plugin framework that allows for incorporating version semantics...
fields.summary: Rich semantics for version numbers

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-3976].
  {panel}

Enable the ability to create different reports. People should be able to create a jar file that contains the necessary class implemenations, etc to generate a custom report. Need to investigate if reports should become velocity templates or if the jar can contain jsps?

Comment from Scott:

.... Perhaps if people package an actions.xml inside their jar, we can load it alongside the normal webwork actions?

Maybe we could make a standard plugin.xml file that has:

<plugin>
services?
listeners?
actions?
actions.xml files?
class implementations?
</plugin>

Then people can have just one XML file to configure, for all their plugin needs?
fields.summary: Enable ability to generate different reports
